explanation:
Correct calculation: \(5 \times 7 \times 24\) (weeks → days → hours)  
Student's calculation: \(5 \times 5 \times 24\)  

The student substituted the number of weeks (5) for the days-per-week conversion factor (7). Instead of multiplying by the correct 7 days/week, they repeated the initial 5 weeks value, inserting it where the conversion factor belonged. This reflects a misapplication of dimensional analysis, where a quantity (5 weeks) was incorrectly reused as a conversion rate.  

The error stems from treating the original quantity (5 weeks) as a repeated multiplier rather than applying the required conversion constant (7 days/week). This distinguishes it from general time-conversion confusion (e.g., mixing hours/minutes) - the specific flaw is duplicating the initial numerical value instead of using the correct proportionality constant.
